title: I wanted to say thanks for making Zoe
body:
Now that some of the Zoe hate has died down, I just wanted to take the time to thank Riot and CertainlyT for making this champion. **Long story inbound.**

I've been playing League since early 2012. At various points, I've mained the likes of Lulu, Lux, Anivia, Malzahar, Teemo and Sona. I'm naturally drawn towards cute, colorful, high-energy, free-spirited characters. Initially, I was totally obsessed with Lulu. She had come out 2 weeks prior to when I started playing so I got to spend the whole week playing her via the free rotation. I thought she was the most amazing character, design-wise, that I'd ever seen in a game. I mained her for a long time. I spent a lot of my early days as a new player on League slowly learning how to use her skills (the fact that she had different effects for enemy/ally really tripped me up a lot). I bought all of her skins, made an alt account with the name "Lulu" in it, bought the Lulu emotes (Delightify and Cup-Yay).

Fast-foward to [the animation of a shimmering bubble that shoots into the fountain](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2G1Gy7xBsjE) and puts people to sleep at the start of a game.

"What in the world is this?" I asked. I was very curious by the in-game teaser, but then I read [Riot's remarks on the matter.](https://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/2017/10/champion-roadmap-october-2017/)

"*We also wanted to take this chance to do something a bit more playful and bubbly as opposed to the dark and serious champions we’ve done recently. The new mage will have unique abilities that haven’t been seen before in League, so hold onto your summoner spells and don’t fall asleep, because change is coming… cataclysmic change. Also, sparkles!*"

Suddenly, I went from curious to buzzing with anticipation. "Is this going to be another Lulu-type character?"

[Then her Champion teaser dropped.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZnVHNJfFMY) My first reactions of it when I messaged my friends went like this:

"LOL she's cute

And potentially very obnoxious

My new main?

We have a Disney character on the rift now

Very annoying

Well that settles it. My new main"

Little did I know that would actually come to be the case.

I must have watched that teaser a dozen times. Here's this obnoxiously happy character in League of Legends. She's jumping across the rift, using three Flashes in a row, being a massive nuisance for her enemies. When she showed up on the PBE I couldn't wait to get a few games in as her. Just like when I first started playing Lulu, Zoe was confusing as hell to control. But, little by little, I got the hang of it and she's now the most fun aspect of the game I've had playing this game in a long time.

Everything about her kit is so much fun. Landing mile-long sleep bubbles is the most satisfying thing ever. However, I tend to focus on the character design aspects. As far as Zoe's character goes, she's perfect. She's bubbly and obnoxiously innocent. She reminds me way too much of myself when I was a little kid. She sings randomly, talks way too much, makes up her own lyrics to songs, makes up words, gets mad when she messes up (miss Q's). The little things about her in-game model are great. Her hair is bigger than she is, she turns to the summoner and sticks out her tongue, she slips and falls randomly when she stops walking. Every time I look at this character, it genuinely makes me happy. She is amazing and I love everything about her.

I embraced the consensus of her being 'annoying' and 'cancerous' and thought it was great how people got mad over her. It made me like the character even more. However, I was really disheartened by the genuine *hate* for the character — both for her personality and because of her kit. I knew she was going to be aggravating, but the community had this almost universal hate for her and it was not a good time to admit you liked Zoe. I'm happy they nerfed her into the ground and then re-adjusted her numbers and abilities to be a lot less ridiculous. Now I can actually play her without her getting banned 90% of the time, or picked by the enemy team the other 10%. 

**tl;dr:** Zoe is the most perfect Champion I've ever played. She's annoyingly bubbly, high-energy and free-spirited. I see a lot of myself in this character. She hits all the right notes for me and I identify with the character more than any other Champion in the game. 

Thank you CertainlyT and everyone else involved so much for this awesome character. You got a lot of flack for designing her, but she's drawn me into the game more than any other Champion ever has. {{champion:142}}

The credit of Zoe's thematic design and artworks go to the other ladies and gentlemen outlined in that infobox.

Well as for me, her gameplay is great too (after they adjusted her numbers and made cleanse stuff properly work on her E).

She has great high and low moments with her W in teamfights and those mile-long Es.  She is extremely vulnerable with bad positioning despite what the gameplay boards say. > Yeah, particularly with such a big player base it's unlikely that any one player is going to have an experience that effectively reflects the averages. 

Is that because the spread is so large, or because the data is bimodal? Differences in distributions imply different necessary actions. Just today's statistics food for thought.

Well the spread is certainly large (for example there are currently 573,658,984,353,378 possible combinations of champions in any given game) but also the sample size of one is infinitesimal compared to a player base in the millions. For example if you roll a D20 once and get a 5 and then assume that 5 is the average result. When it comes to LoL, at a conservative estimate, a single player would have to play ~30,000 games of LoL per month to achieve a reasonable confidence level.

Well the beautiful thing about working in riot is you can pull your data from many individuals, so the distribution of all experiences can be drawn upon instead of just from an individual in order to answer the question of expected variance of an individual's experience. The bimodal distribution in experiences that i suspect exists and was alluding to is between people who permaban yas vs. those who don't. 

If this underlying distribution is significantly bimodal in this way then the "background" games which contain a player who permabans yasuo can be subtracted and the "signal" games which represents the experiences of those who do not constantly ban him can be properly assessed. In this situation yasuo has potentially two problems, one being why so many players are of the proclivity to permaban him causing the bimodal distribution in the first place, and any other potential problems (which may or may not even exist) would be uncovered from the signal games which would not be assess-able without this kind of subtraction. 

If the underlying distribution is not significantly bimodal then that means that yasuo's high banrate comes from many people who comparatively infrequently ban yasuo, and the spread of experiences around yasuo's pickrate is closer to normal and likely lower in deviation, implying a smaller set of potential problems that people are more unified on. 

In this example a large spread implies different necessary action compared to a bimodal underlying distribution.
